title: In his discussion, John Delaney claims that "medical care for all" will close hospitals unsupported by evidence.
text: In the first democratic presidential debate, former representative John Delaney (doctor) He outlined his opposition to "medical care for all" and focused on one of the potential losers: hospitals. He said, "If you go to every hospital in this country and ask them one question: "How would it have been for you last year if each of your bills had been paid at the rate of medical care?" Each hospital director said that they would close." This is a difference in an industry-to-industry discussion point. Hospitals say that medical care for all means substantial reductions in income for them. On the other hand, they argue that this will lead many to closure. However, Delaney ' s claim -- which has received a great deal of online and post-discussion news coverage -- has attracted our attention. Are you gonna close the "everyone" hospital? Did someone actually ask "every hospital in the country"? We decided to dig in. Delaney's employees told us that his point came from three sources. First, the fact that medical care pays hospitals an average of 87 cents per dollar of cost. Second, a federal report indicates that "more than two thirds of hospitals lose money on inpatient medical care services." Third: Delaney, his crew said, "He was asking this question in the rural hospitals he visited during the campaign." The experts with whom we spoke offered a different approach, especially since his evidence is not strong enough to support his claim. In addition, they told us that the potential impact of universal medical care on hospitals would be much more precise - and it is not at all clear that "each hospital" will be closed, and while some will do worse, some may be better. The different hospitals, the different effects "it really depends on which hospitals you're talking about," said Gerard Anderson, Professor of Health Policy at Johns Hopkins University and an expert in hospital pricing. Hospitals that treat a large number of uninsured patients - people who can be said to receive coverage under the universal medical care approach - are likely to increase their revenues under the new system because they will no longer face the financial pressure of unimpaired care. However, hospitals that treat many privately insured patients, with which insurance prices are often negotiated in a favourable manner, will experience a decline in income. Economists are quick to point out that the latter scenario is not necessarily bad. It is well known that American spending on health care is higher than in other developed countries. Research indicates that hospitals, especially those with a significant impact or market power, are among the main drivers of these high costs because they are able to negotiate much higher prices with insurance companies.
